results.title: Small towns, big picture: a journey in building community
results.creator_credit: Philip Ashton, Judy Spokes, Maureen Rogers and Image Link
results.brief_description:
Five country towns in Central Victoria - Dunolly,
Wedderburn, Carisbrook, Maldon and Talbot - have been
involved in a social experimental project called “Small Towns Big Picture” for the last two years or more with the
Centre for Sustainable Regional Communities, La Trobe
University, Bendigo under the leadership of Dr Maureen
Rogers. Concern was being expressed about the demise of small country towns and their future, economically,
socially and environmentally and the main intention of the
Project was to develop a toolkit for measuring the “health” of a community - a benchmark for sustainability. With the assistance of Judy Spokes and the Cultural Development Network seven artists were commissioned to work with the communities and the researchers. Workshops were established incorporating the community, including the Energy Footprint Project and a Community Cohesion Project. Craig Christie (playwright) has been working on creating and producing a musical play in Carisbrook capturing the issues from the Community Cohesion focus group and auditioning the local
communities to perform in the play. This documentary
provides an inside view of the workings of “Small Towns Big Picture” and includes interviews with artists, project
leaders, councillors, teachers and members of the
community.

results.title: Project the right image
results.brief_description:
English production, NOT made by the Department of Agriculture.

Details hot to and how not to project a 16mm film using a social church gathering as the backdrop. Stars a bumbling projectionist and a priest who first do everything the wrong way and then do everything the correct way.

Comical (in a daggy way) throughout with good use of slapstick humour. Also contains an amusing, very dry voiceover.

results.title: Irati-wanti: the poison leave it
results.brief_description: “All of us were living when the government used the country for the bomb. The Government thought what they knew what they were doing then. We know the poison from the radioactive dump will go down under the ground and leak into the water.” The Kupa Piti Kungka Tjuta, a council of elder Aboriginal women from Coober Pedy, have been campaigning against the Federal Government’s plans to build a national radioactive waste repository on their traditional lands in the South Australian desert. Four years after this documentary was made they are still fighting. A confronting documentary about Australia’s history of Nuclear Testing and its impact on the indigenous inhabitants of so called ‘uninhabited’ land. For more information visit www.irantiwanti.org

results.title: Juggling the elements
results.creator_credit: Katrina Sawyer, Sakshi Productions, Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Stewart Lodge and Tracey Power
results.brief_description: Tracey Power has maintained her courage, honesty and humour despite having suffered abuse and trauma at the hands of her family and the state from birth. Tracey looks different, she sometines has a shaved head and many tattoos and she is scarred from ‘slashing up’. Tracey acts differently, she doesn’t follow the social rules of behaviour. She loves trams and has the word ‘tram’ tattooed on her hand. She has a mental illness which has led her to being institutuionalised a number of times. She is both street wise and disarmingly trusting and generous. She looks very tough, yet she is very sensitive and vulnerable. She tells her story ‘in your face’ and she tells it ‘straight’ about abuse, institutions, drug addiction, mental illness, slashing up, giving up her baby for adoption and also about friendships, fun, love and hope. Tracey’s story tells us alot about living with mental illness, about being different and about surviving without losing your spirit or humanity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Katrina Sawyer, Sakshi Productions, Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Stewart Lodge and Tracey Power

results.title: Transit: SteamRail workshops
results.creator_credit: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV
results.brief_description:
This episode of ‘Transit’ is the ninth in a series of ten-quarter hour episodes produced by Northern Access Television in 1998.
‘Transit’ was a series of Community TV programs produced about Melbourne’s and Victoria’s Public Transport System and Transport Museum Groups by Michael Costello, a former Melbourne Tram Conductor. Other episodes included episodes on the Bendigo and Ballarat Tramway Museums, the Melbourne Transit Band, the Tramcar Restaurant and many others. In the 1998 series, various members of Northern Access TV assisted in the production of the programs. The programs were all made using volunteers from Northern Access TV on Mini DV cameras.
This episode looks at the SteamRail Workshops, located in the former Newport Railway Workshops. It consists of an interview where David McLauchlan interviews Keith Finlay, secretary of SteamRail Victoria Inc. This non-profit volunteer based association aims to preserve Victoria’s steam powered rail heritage and keep examples of them running for public tours to many destinations on Victoria’s Rail Network. In addition to preserving the days of steam-powered trains, the group also has sections that are dedicated to preserving Diesel and Electric rolling stock as well. During the interview, we see examples of the work undertaken on the carriages and associated equipment.

results.title: [Release prints compilation]
results.brief_description:
1. Wall to Wall Wool - Documents the process of wool carpet production from design illustrations of a bunch of flowers to the manufacture of finished carpet with similar design. Primarily focuses on the many types of machinery used to create the carpet. Contains nice images of a carpet-making factory, specifically the colourful flower-patterned carpet juxtaposed within an industrial backdrop. Good ‘The End’. (12m 44sec)

  2. Melbourne: Festival City - Made by the Victorian Tourist Development Authority in the 1960s. Essentially an ad for Melbourne, focusing on the ‘highly popular’ Moomba Festival. Great images of large crowds watching the Moomba parade as well as having fun on rides, watching watersports and eating/drinking (including Latte drinkers). Also shows the ‘recently completed’ Sydney Myer Music Bowl, footage of a game of football at the MCG and highlights Melbourne as the ‘Fashion Capital’. Nice closing shot of the city, focusing on St. Pauls and a Fed Square-less Flinders St, as well as the Yarra. Good titles and ‘The End’. (10 mins)

  3. Hydatids - Australian Wool Bureau production. Highlights the dangers of Hydatid disease and the ease of which it can be both contracted and negated. This includes washing hands after having contact with dogs and boiling all sheep offal before feeding it to dogs. Contains footage of a farmer gutting a sheep and cute diagrams of how the hydatids disease can spread from sheep to dogs to humans. (10 mins)

results.title: Melbourne: festival city
results.creator_credit: Gordon C. Lloyd, Cinesound and Tourist Development Authority of Victoria
results.brief_description: Melbourne’s Moomba festival - the city comes alive with processions, regattas, the Herald open air art show, music under the stars at the Myer Music Bowl, and the crowning of the Moomba Queen. The film also shows some of the Melbourne landscape and the background of daily life; Melbourne’s economic expansion; the Melbourne Cup, the race for which the nation stands still; Australian Rules Football, drawing crowds of over 50,000; fine golf courses; hunting; night life. It closes with a coverage of the Moomba procession, with all its varied floats, including the Bunyip and the Chinese dragon.
